content.description:
The Inverted Yield Curve is always a good predictor of an upcoming recession. Navigating the beta and fighting the pump is the key, or you'll see a drop in your portfolio. A fun start leads to the steep and cryptic crux, which is followed by pumpy moves to the anchors.

The line was originally poached after being red-tagged following its development; however, a key hold at the crux broke off afterward making the beta different and more difficult. While I didn't get the FA, this route has been a real gift for me. I've been working it off and on for over a year, and with the recent send, it marks some of the most difficult climbing that I've been able to string together. I'm not super familiar with the 5.12 end of things, but other ascentionists have compared it to the

Eye of the Tiger

(at the main wall) in difficulty, and it took me way more tries than

Mufasa

(at Mill Creek Block) which I thought may be soft for .12a. Either way, get on it, and we'll see where the consensus puts the grade at.
content.location:
The Inverted Yield Curve is on the left side of the crag and shares the anchors with

Derivative

on the right.

content.description:
Derivative begins in the corner system at the base of the Correction Crag. There's a definitive crux at mid height, but the steepness of the wall will make you earn the chains.

This is a good warm-up for its much harder neighbor to the left.
content.location:
Derivative tackles the right side of this cool panel of rock and shares anchors with

The Inverted Yield Curve

on the left.
